articles.headline: Jeffrey Immelt Is Putting His Own Stamp on Jack Welch’s G.E.
articles.snippet: The C.E.O. has come to the recognition that G.E.’s real strength is industrial engineering, dealing a blow to his predecessor’s initiatives.
articles.abstract: The C.E.O. has come to the recognition that G.E.’s real strength is industrial engineering, dealing a blow to his predecessor’s initiatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey R. Immelt, chief executive of General Electric, was speaking at Stanford Business School a few years ago when a student asked him pointedly: How tough was it to be the next act at G.E. after the celebrated two-decade tenure of Jack Welch?

articles.headline: Ex-Blackwater Guards Given Long Terms for Killing Iraqis
articles.snippet: One member of the private American security firm received a life term and three others 30 years after they were convicted of killing 14 unarmed Iraqis in Baghdad’s Nisour Square in 2007.
articles.abstract: One member of the private American security firm received a life term and three others 30 years after they were convicted of killing 14 unarmed Iraqis in Baghdad’s Nisour Square in 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One by one, four former Blackwater security contractors wearing blue jumpsuits and leg irons stood before a federal judge on Monday and spoke publicly for the first time since a deadly 2007 shooting in Iraq.

articles.headline: Treasury Officials Increase Efforts With Finances of Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: The efforts indicate that the island’s financial problems, which have been simmering for years, are reaching a critical point.
articles.abstract: The efforts indicate that the island’s financial problems, which have been simmering for years, are reaching a critical point.
articles.lead_paragraph: Antonio Weiss, the former Wall Street banker who became a top adviser to the Treasury secretary this year, has made two trips to Puerto Rico in recent weeks.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Health Insurance Shoppers Look to Limited Networks to Save Money
articles.snippet: Consumers seem increasingly comfortable with narrow lists of hospitals or doctors, if it gets them a cheaper plan.
articles.abstract: Consumers seem increasingly comfortable with narrow lists of hospitals or doctors, if it gets them a cheaper plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: In all the turmoil in health care, one surprising truth is emerging: Consumers seem increasingly comfortable trading a greater choice of hospitals or doctors for a health plan that costs significantly less money.

articles.headline: BlackRock’s Chief, Laurence Fink, Urges Other C.E.O.s to Stop Being So Nice to Investors
articles.snippet: Laurence D. Fink, chief of BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, warns of harm in dividends and stock buybacks.
articles.abstract: Laurence D. Fink, chief of BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, warns of harm in dividends and stock buybacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, the chief executives of 500 of the nation’s largest companies will receive a letter in the mail that will most likely surprise them.

articles.headline: Wage Effort Poses Test for Clinton Campaign
articles.snippet: A nationwide strike may provide the first test for the Clinton campaign at managing the desire of voters and party activists for an aggressive approach to mitigating income inequality.
articles.abstract: A nationwide strike may provide the first test for the Clinton campaign at managing the desire of voters and party activists for an aggressive approach to mitigating income inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: The grass-roots energy building around the minimum wage issue may upend Hillary Rodham Clinton’s plans to ease into proposing specific economic policies.

articles.headline: Stressing Youth, Marco Rubio Joins 2016 Field
articles.snippet: Senator Marco Rubio offers new energy for the Republican Party, but a challenge is whether voters seek another charismatic first-term senator with a compelling story.
articles.abstract: Senator Marco Rubio offers new energy for the Republican Party, but a challenge is whether voters seek another charismatic first-term senator with a compelling story.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Senator Marco Rubio, the 43-year-old son of Cuban immigrants, on Monday declared that it was time for his generation to lead the country, portraying himself as the youthful future of a Republican Party that has struggled to connect with an increasingly diverse electorate.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Nuclear Reactors in Japan Remain Closed by Judge’s Order
articles.snippet: The reactors at a plant in Fukui Prefecture had been expected to return to service after the introduction of post-Fukushima safety standards.
articles.abstract: The reactors at a plant in Fukui Prefecture had been expected to return to service after the introduction of post-Fukushima safety standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Fukui Prefecture, with 13 commercial nuclear reactors clustered along a short, rugged coastline, has earned the area a reputation as a political stronghold for the atomic power industry. Nuclear-friendly politicians dominate most of Fukui’s government offices, and the region is nicknamed Genpatsu Ginza, or Nuclear Alley.

articles.headline: Obama Yields, Allowing Congress Say on Iran Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: President Obama would sign a compromise bill giving Congress a voice on the proposed nuclear accord as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in rare unanimity, moved the legislation to the full Senate for a vote.
articles.abstract: President Obama would sign a compromise bill giving Congress a voice on the proposed nuclear accord as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in rare unanimity, moved the legislation to the full Senate for a vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House relented on Tuesday and said President Obama would sign a compromise bill giving Congress a voice on the proposed nuclear accord with Iran as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in rare unanimous agreement, moved the legislation to the full Senate for a vote.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Driver’s License Suspensions Create Cycle of Debt
articles.snippet: Some states have rethought the suspensions over unpaid debt amid concerns that the policy hurts poor residents without achieving its intended goals.
articles.abstract: Some states have rethought the suspensions over unpaid debt amid concerns that the policy hurts poor residents without achieving its intended goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEBANON, Tenn. — The last time Kenneth Seay lost his job, at an industrial bakery that offered health insurance and Christmas bonuses, it was because he had been thrown in jail for legal issues stemming from a revoked driver’s license. Same with the three jobs before that.
